chunk_summary: Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation in typhoid fever arise from Peyer’s patch ulceration, requiring prompt diagnosis, supportive care, and surgical intervention in severe cases.
learning_objectives: Recognize signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding in typhoid fever, such as melena, hematochezia, and unexplained hemoglobin drop.
Understand the management priorities for gastrointestinal bleeding, including hemodynamic stabilization and transfusion protocols.
Identify and manage intestinal perforation as a surgical emergency in enteric fever.
Learn the role of broad-spectrum antibiotics in secondary intra-abdominal contamination.
key_facts: Gastrointestinal complications typically occur after more than one week of illness, especially with delayed or incomplete treatment.
Signs of gastrointestinal bleeding include melena, hematochezia, pallor, tachycardia, and hemoglobin drop.
Most bleeds are self-limited, but recurrent or massive bleeding requires urgent senior review and possible surgical or endoscopic intervention.
Intestinal perforation presents with severe abdominal pain, guarding, rigidity, distension, or shock and requires immediate surgical repair.
Antibiotics for perforation must cover Salmonella and secondary intra-abdominal contamination, including anaerobes.
Evidence-based supportive care measures are essential
reference_quote: Gastrointestinal bleeding should be suspected with melena, hematochezia, pallor, tachycardia out of proportion to fever, or an unexplained fall in hemoglobin. (Source: StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf)
document_key_topics: Role of antibiotics in enteric fever complications
